Irish: Músclaím de ghnáth thart fá leath i ndiaidh a seacht.
English: I usually wake up around half past seven.

Irish: Ithim mo bhricfeasta idir a hocht agus leath i ndiaidh a hocht.
English: I eat my breakfast between eight and half past eight.

Irish: Téim ag obair thart fá cheathrú go dtí a naoi.
English: I go to work at around a quarter to nine.

Irish: Téim chun na scoile ag a naoi a chlog.
English: I go to school at nine o'clock.
ASKING SOMEONE WHAT TIME THEY DO SOMETHING

Irish: Cad é an t-am a n-éiríonn tú achan mhaidin?
English: What time do you get up every morning?

Irish: Cad é an t-am a dtéann tú ag obair achan mhaidin?
English: What time do you go to work every morning?

Irish: Cad é an t-am a mbíonn do dhinnéar agat?
English: What time do you have your dinner?

Irish: Bíonn mo lón agam idir a haon agus a dó.
English: I have my lunch between one and two.

Irish: Bím sa bhaile de ghnáth ag a sé.
Bíonn mo dhinnéar agam sa bhaile.
English: I have my dinner at home.
We've already come across tá many times during this course. When you're referring to something that recurs, either frequently or infrequently, you need to use the present habitual form:
(I am always tired in the evening.)

Irish: Bím mall i gcónaí maidin Dé luain.
English: (I am always late on Monday morning.)

Irish: Cad é a dhéanann tú i rith an lae?
English: What do you do during the day?

Irish: Cad é a dhéanann tú tráthnóna?
English: What do you do in the evening?
ASKING SOMEONE IF THEY DO A PARTICULAR THING

Irish: An dtéann tú amach go minic?
An amharcann tú ar an teilifís?
